channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: California's top court limits what government may charge for public records
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Government agencies in California may not charge for redacting documents sought in public records requests, the California Supreme Court rules.
item.content:encoded: Government agencies in California may not charge for redacting documents sought in public records requests, the California Supreme Court rules.

media:content.media:description: Justice Leondra Kruger working and poses for a portrait in her downtown office, was appointed by Jerry Brown to the California Supreme Court. She votes more conservatively than the other two Brown appointees because she prefers the law to develop very slowly. (David Butow / For The Times)

item.title: Earthquake: 3.5 quake near Soledad, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Thursday at 12:19 p.m. Pacific time 11 miles from Soledad, Calif., according to the USGS.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Thursday at 12:19 p.m. Pacific time 11 miles from Soledad, Calif., according to the USGS.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported May 28 at 12:19 p.m. Pacific time 11 miles from Soledad, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: After K-9 is stabbed, Fullerton police shoot and kill knife-wielding man
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The police dog was taken to a veterinary hospital and underwent emergency surgery. He is expected to make a full recovery.
item.content:encoded: The police dog was taken to a veterinary hospital and underwent emergency surgery. He is expected to make a full recovery.

media:content.media:description: A knife was recovered at the scene of a police shooting in Fullerton late Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus cases spiked after these counties reopened. Now, officials are scaling back
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Lassen County reported its first cases, and Sonoma County has seen an increase after being among the first in the state to ease stay-at-home orders.
item.content:encoded: Lassen County reported its first cases, and Sonoma County has seen an increase after being among the first in the state to ease stay-at-home orders.

media:content.media:description: In this photo taken Wednesday, April 1, 2020, are the empty grounds of the historic Buena Vista Winery in Sonoma, Calif. Wineries that want to stay viable and connected to their customers during the coronavirus pandemic are harnessing platforms such as Facebook Live to offer virtual wine experiences. Tasting rooms in California shut down last month after the governor ordered businesses to close to slow the spread of the new virus. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: 3 alleged L.A. gang members arrested in fatal shooting of single mom
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: 'An overwhelming amount of video evidence' helped police arrest three alleged gang members in connection with the shooting of a 28-year-old woman.
item.content:encoded: 'An overwhelming amount of video evidence' helped police arrest three alleged gang members in connection with the shooting of a 28-year-old woman.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 28: Family members of Magali Alberto, who was shot and killed about 12:20 a.m. April 26 at traffic light, at a press conference held by LAPD to announce the arrest of three suspects. 77th Area Community Police Station on Thursday, May 28, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California nears 4,000 coronavirus deaths
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Hannah Fry, Phil Willon
item.description: While much of California is steadily lifting restrictions, two Northern California counties have had to roll back plans as coronavirus infections jumped.
item.content:encoded: While much of California is steadily lifting restrictions, two Northern California counties have had to roll back plans as coronavirus infections jumped.

media:content.media:description: TEMECULA, CA - MAY 26: Gene Kelley, right, co-owner of Skyline Barber Shop cuts Dan Collins, left, hair on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Temecula, CA. Gov. Gavin Newsom says California counties that have been granted regional variances allowing more types of businesses to reopen can now permit the reopening of barbershops and hair salons, with modifications such asâ¨protective gear and face coverings during the coronavirus pandemic. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Families call for shutdown of Vallejo nursing home with 102 COVID infections, 13 deaths
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Nearly a quarter of all COVID-19 cases in Solano County, Calif., can be linked to one nursing home in Vallejo. Families want the facility shut down.
item.content:encoded: Nearly a quarter of all COVID-19 cases in Solano County, Calif., can be linked to one nursing home in Vallejo. Families want the facility shut down.

media:content.media:description: A sign is displayed near the entrance of the Windsor Vallejo Care Center on Tuesday, May 5, 2020, in Vallejo, Calif. Numerous residents and staff members at the center have tested positive for coronavirus. (AP Photo/Ben Margot)

item.title: How to search for and find a new rental during coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Jack Harris
item.description: Finding a rental in L.A. was hard enough before the global pandemic. Here's a guide to how to search and move in Southern California, and stay safe.
item.content:encoded: Finding a rental in L.A. was hard enough before the global pandemic. Here's a guide to how to search and move in Southern California, and stay safe.

media:content.media:description: A large apartment is advertised for rent at the corner of California Boulevard and Oakland Avenue on October for 7, 2019 in Pasadena, California. Landlords say state rent caps may force them to raise rents more frequently.(Gina Ferazzi/Los AngelesTimes)

item.title: 700 Chino inmates to be transferred as coronavirus sweeps prison
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The prisoners have tested negative but have histories that make them vulnerable in a facility where the coronavirus has infected every dormitory.
item.content:encoded: The prisoners have tested negative but have histories that make them vulnerable in a facility where the coronavirus has infected every dormitory.

media:content.media:description: Housing in the Elm dorm at California Institution for Men in Chino.

item.title: Record crowds trash Ventura County waterfall with litter, human waste
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Paradise Falls in Wildwood Regional Park in northwestern Thousand Oaks will remain closed until further notice, conservation agency says.
item.content:encoded: Paradise Falls in Wildwood Regional Park in northwestern Thousand Oaks will remain closed until further notice, conservation agency says.

media:content.media:description: THOUSAND OAKS, CA -- APRIL 9, 2019: Kirstin Keagy of Ventura enjoys the view of Paradise Falls at Wildwood Regional Park in Thousand Oaks. Rains have pumped up the area's waterfalls. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Sunbathing, lounging now allowed at Ventura County beaches
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The county's decision to permit passive use follows similar action in the coastal cities of Ventura, Oxnard and Port Hueneme.
item.content:encoded: The county's decision to permit passive use follows similar action in the coastal cities of Ventura, Oxnard and Port Hueneme.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - APRIL 22: Richard and Cindy Garcia, middle, join people enjoying the surf and sand at Hueneme Beach Wednesday which has a soft opening with restrictions as Ventura County on Saturday modified its stay-at-home order to permit some businesses to reopen and some gatherings to take place for the first time since the restrictions were issued to fight the spread of the coronavirus COVID-19. "We needed to breathe some clean air and be around birds, not people," said Richard. Ventura on Wednesday, April 22, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Photos: Black Lives Matter-LA joins national protests over the the death of George Floyd
item.dc:creator: Times Staff
item.description: Photos of protests in downtown Los Angeles after the Minneapolis man was killed by police.
item.content:encoded: Photos of protests in downtown Los Angeles after the Minneapolis man was killed by police.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 27: Two people stand on a police vehicle during a Black Lives Matter protest in downtown on Wednesday, May 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Reopening California could easily backfire into second wave without masks and distancing, officials warn
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Rong-Gong Lin II, Cindy Chang
item.description: Health officials have stressed that with the easing of stay-at-home orders comes the potential to further spread the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Health officials have stressed that with the easing of stay-at-home orders comes the potential to further spread the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: BOYLE HEIGHTS, CA-MAY 27, 2020: Daniela Prieto, 21, an employee at Deportes Prieto, a retail business on 1st St. in Boyle Heights, disinfects inside the store that is currently only allowing customers to pre-order merchandise and pick up at the store. The business re-opened on Monday with curbside pick-up only after previously being closed due to the coronavirus. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'I had to do something': Black barbers and stylists go underground as L.A. salons stay shut
item.dc:creator: Angel Jennings
item.description: In black communities, where barbershops and salons are cultural institutions and gathering places, the lockdown has hit barbers and stylists hard.
item.content:encoded: In black communities, where barbershops and salons are cultural institutions and gathering places, the lockdown has hit barbers and stylists hard.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 16: Unable to open their Mid-City Salon, hair stylists Tia Rose of North Hollywood and Christina Rose of West Covina styles a clients hair in an AirBnb in order to earn a living during the coronavirus pandemic on Saturday, May 16, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Salons across Los Angeles have been classified as nonessential businesses forcing some hairstylist to take their business underground. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Vandalism during heated L.A. protest over George Floyd death sparks concern from police
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Demonstrators blocked the 101 Freeway, vandalized two CHP cruisers and spray-painted graffiti on LAPD headquarters.
item.content:encoded: Demonstrators blocked the 101 Freeway, vandalized two CHP cruisers and spray-painted graffiti on LAPD headquarters.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 27: Protesters surround a police vehicle on the 101 freeway near downtown Los Angeles on Wednesday, May 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. A protester smashed the back window with a skateboard. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus ravages poorer L.A. communities while slowing in wealthier ones, data show
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza, Ben Poston, Ryan Menezes
item.description: Since April 17, coronavirus infection rates have surged in L.A. County's poorer neighborhoods, while cases have risen far more slowly in richer areas.
item.content:encoded: Since April 17, coronavirus infection rates have surged in L.A. County's poorer neighborhoods, while cases have risen far more slowly in richer areas.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18: Maria Banderas, left, answers questions from medical assistant Dolores Becerra before entering the room where she will receive the oral swab test for coronavirus during walk-in coronavirus testing at St. John's Well Child and Family Center in South Los Angeles, one of the South and Central LA neighborhoods hit hard by the coronavirus Covid-19. South Central on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California requires universal testing at nursing homes, overruling L.A. County
item.dc:creator: Jack Dolan
item.description: California's new guidelines come as other states are pushing for mass testing in nursing homes.
item.content:encoded: California's new guidelines come as other states are pushing for mass testing in nursing homes.

media:content.media:description: RESEDA, CA - MARCH 25: A worker at Eisenberg Village nursing home screens all incoming for symptoms of the coronavirus on Wednesday, March 25, 2020 in Reseda, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California reopening speeds up even as state hits 100,000 confirmed coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Hannah Fry
item.description: From barber shops to shopping malls to restaurants, many businesses shuttered for months began to come back to life this week as government officials rapidly lifted stay-at-home orders that helped slow the spread of coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: From barber shops to shopping malls to restaurants, many businesses shuttered for months began to come back to life this week as government officials rapidly lifted stay-at-home orders that helped slow the spread of coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: ARCADIA, CALIF. - MAY 27, 2020. A sign taped to a lightpost tells customers about curbside pickup services at a store in the Santa Anita Mall in Arcadia on Wednesday, May 27, 2020. Stores remained mostly closed despite restrictions being lifted for for in-store shopping throughout California. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County sheriff reviewing deputies' actions in video recorded by suspects complaining of harassment

item.description: The Senate plan assumes additional money for schools and social services will come from the federal government by early September.
item.content:encoded: The Senate plan assumes additional money for schools and social services will come from the federal government by early September.

item.title: Los Angeles police fatally shoot man wielding 'sword-type weapon' in North Hollywood
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Los Angeles Police Department officers fatally shot a man who was wielding a bladed weapon, the agency said. Officers were called for a dispute between neighbors.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles Police Department officers fatally shot a man who was wielding a bladed weapon, the agency said. Officers were called for a dispute between neighbors.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles police shot a man armed with a "sword-type" weapon in North Hollywood after responding to a call of a dispute between neighbors, the Police Department said.

item.title: Assemblyman Bill Brough loses committee assignments after sexual misconduct investigation
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Assemblyman William Brough (R-Dana Point) was removed from all committee assignments after a state investigation found he made inappropriate comments and engaged in unwanted touching with a woman who complained to the Legislature.
item.content:encoded: Assemblyman William Brough (R-Dana Point) was removed from all committee assignments after a state investigation found he made inappropriate comments and engaged in unwanted touching with a woman who complained to the Legislature.

media:content.media:description: Assemblyman William Brough, R-Dana Point, right, talks with Marie Waldron, R-Escondido, Tuesday, Aug. 30, 2016, in Sacramento, Calif. Lawmakers are working through hundreds of bills as they try to complete their work before the end of the two-year legislative session on Aug. 31. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

Orange County beaches are currently open for active recreation, which includes swimming, surfing, and running. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Placer County pushes to reopen gyms, nail salons, tourist venues
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Northern California county is asking for "specific flexibility to reopen for tourism no later than June 1."
item.content:encoded: The Northern California county is asking for "specific flexibility to reopen for tourism no later than June 1."

media:content.media:description: GRASS VALLEY, MAY 22, 2020: Jerry O'Brien, of Placer County, holding sign, joins other demonstrators outside Grass Valley City Hall, in a rally, protesting California's stay at home order. O'Brien said that his daughter owns a small business in Grass Valley. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Cash, casinos and a sexual harassment payout: Former Huizar aide agrees to plead guilty
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Joel Rubin, Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: A former aide to L.A. City Councilman Jose Huizar has agreed to plead guilty to felony racketeering in the federal "pay-to-play" investigation at City Hall.

item.title: Newsom says rules for reopening California fitness centers coming 'in a week or so'
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Gov. Newsom says the state would release guidelines "in a week or so" for gyms and other facilities to reopen in California.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Newsom says the state would release guidelines "in a week or so" for gyms and other facilities to reopen in California.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON PARK, CALIF. - APR. 29, 2020. Pedestrians walk past a shuttered gym along Pacific Avenue in Huntington Park on Wednesday, April 29, 2020. California's unemployment rate has skyrocketed since the statewide coronavirus shutdown took effect. Nationwide it's the highest since the Great Depression. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: O.C. company profited off fake coronavirus tests, prosecutors say

item.content:encoded: A Huntington Beach company falsely promised buyers an FDA-approved coronavirus home testing kit with results in 10 minutes, L.A. city attorney says.

item.title: California coronavirus milestone: 100,000 cases. 'It hasn't ended'

item.description: The number of coronavirus infections in California surpassed 100,000 as Gov. Gavin Newsom loosens more stay-at-home restrictions.
item.content:encoded: The number of coronavirus infections in California surpassed 100,000 as Gov. Gavin Newsom loosens more stay-at-home restrictions.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 26, 2020: Drive-through coronavirus testing at Dodger Stadium in Elysian Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. Archdiocese could resume daily Mass, scheduled confessions next week
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: L.A. Archdiocese plans to begin gradually reopening churches, with measures to prevent crowding and physical contact, as soon as next week.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Archdiocese plans to begin gradually reopening churches, with measures to prevent crowding and physical contact, as soon as next week.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- APRIL 21: Francisco Lorenzo prays in front of the closed doors of the Immaculate Conception Catholic Church in downtown on Tuesday, April 21, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The Archdiocese of Los Angeles has announced the suspension of public Masses, at least until March 29. "I deeply regret that we are forced to temporarily suspend public celebration of the Mass in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles," Archbishop Jose H. Gomez said in a statement released March 16. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Battle between Trump and California over car pollution heads to court
item.dc:creator: Anna M. Phillips, Tony Barboza
item.description: California, joined by 22 other states, is suing the Trump administration over its decision to weaken regulations limiting auto emissions.
item.content:encoded: California, joined by 22 other states, is suing the Trump administration over its decision to weaken regulations limiting auto emissions.

media:content.media:description: Three out of every four would-be home buyers focus at least somewhat on cutting their commuting costs, according to a National Assn. of Realtors survey. Above, the 110 Freeway on a Friday afternoon.

item.title: Runyon Canyon reopens for hiking with new coronavirus safety measures in place
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Cindy Chang
item.description: Runyon Canyon reopens with limits on the number of people allowed in, a one-way hiking trail and cameras and electric counters to monitor crowds.
item.content:encoded: Runyon Canyon reopens with limits on the number of people allowed in, a one-way hiking trail and cameras and electric counters to monitor crowds.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 27: Hikers enter Runyon Canyon Park at the North entrance on Mulholland Drive in the Hollywood hills on Wednesday morning as the popular park has been reopened and is closely monitored by L.A. City person new under COVID-19 safety guidelines. Visitors are still required to wear masks at the park and people are instructed to walk in lanes with directional arrows trying to maximize social distancing. Hollywood on Wednesday, May 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Here is what can now reopen in L.A. County, and here is what is still closed
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini, Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: Malls? Movie theaters? Hair salons? Here's a look at which L.A. County businesses can now open and which ones are still closed.
item.content:encoded: Malls? Movie theaters? Hair salons? Here's a look at which L.A. County businesses can now open and which ones are still closed.

media:content.media:description: BREA, CA - MAY 26: Shoppers walk around the Brea Mall, which reopened Tuesday, where some of the mall's stores opened their doors to shoppers as the state emerges from shutdown orders enacted to slow the spread of the coronavirus. In new guidelines released yesterday ... the re-opening of retail stores for socially distanced shopping experiences remains subject to approval from officials in each of the state's counties. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: California is reopening too quickly, posing 'very serious risk,' health officer warns
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II

item.content:encoded: A key architect of the nation's first coronavirus stay-at-home order says California's fast pace of lifting restrictions "poses a very serious risk."

media:content.media:description: Santa Clara County Public Health Department Director Dr. Sara Cody speaks during a news conference in San Jose, Calif., on Friday, Feb. 28, 2020. Santa Clara County health officials confirmed a second case of unknown origin of the novel coronavirus. (Anda Chu/Bay Area News Group via AP)

item.title: Shooting leaves 5 wounded outside South L.A. apartment complex
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Five people were taken to hospitals after a shooting on Berendo Avenue near 119th Street in South Los Angeles.
item.content:encoded: Five people were taken to hospitals after a shooting on Berendo Avenue near 119th Street in South Los Angeles.

media:content.media:description: SOUTH LOS ANGELES, MAY 26, 2020 - An investigation is underway after five people were hospitalized following a shooting Tuesday night outside a South Los Angeles apartment complex. The L.A. County Fire Department said the shooting was reported near the intersection of 119th Street and Berendo Avenue in the neighborhood of Athens at about 10:40 p.m. None of the injuries are considered life-threatening

item.title: A silent coronavirus threat looms large as California reopens businesses
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: At Eaton Canyon, a popular Pasadena hiking area, so many people crowded the trail Saturday morning â many without masks and jammed close together â that rangers shut it down for the rest of the month.
item.content:encoded: At Eaton Canyon, a popular Pasadena hiking area, so many people crowded the trail Saturday morning â many without masks and jammed close together â that rangers shut it down for the rest of the month.

media:content.media:description: People walk at the boardwalk in Venice Beach during the first day of the Memorial Day holiday weekend amid the novel Coronavirus, COVID-19, pandemic in California on May 23, 2020. - Los Angeles County officials announced May 22, 2020, that beach bike paths and some beach parking lots will reopen and curbside service at indoor malls will be permitted. The county reopened its beaches a week ago but kept beach parking lots, bike paths, piers and boardwalks closed. (Photo by Apu GOMES / AFP) (Photo by APU GOMES/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: California bullet train could end up needing subsidies, despite promises to voters
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.description: Opponents of the state's high-speed rail project say California is preparing to violate a 2008 ballot measure promise not to use state subsidies for operation of the bullet train. Proponents disagree.
item.content:encoded: Opponents of the state's high-speed rail project say California is preparing to violate a 2008 ballot measure promise not to use state subsidies for operation of the bullet train. Proponents disagree.

media:content.media:description: Workers tie rebar on a support structure located on the South end of the Cedar Viaduct section of the California High Speed Rail Project.

item.title: One-way halls, lunch at desk, playing alone. L.A. schools could reopen with stark rules
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Sonali Kohli
item.description: L.A. schools could reopen with stark rules: One-way halls, lunch at desk, playing alone
item.content:encoded: L.A. schools could reopen with stark rules: One-way halls, lunch at desk, playing alone

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 26: Los Angeles County Office of Education Supt. Debra Duardo tours Cerritos Elementary School in Glendale on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Powder keg' at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison with 110 cases of COVID-19 in two weeks
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Until May 13, none of the 2,306 men incarcerated at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison had tested positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. More than 100 inmates have been infected since.
item.content:encoded: Until May 13, none of the 2,306 men incarcerated at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison had tested positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. More than 100 inmates have been infected since.

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J. ÂÂ Â CHINO: AUG. 10, 2009: As viewed through the afternoon heat waves, a corrections officer looks out from a tower over barbed wire fences and transport busses at the California Institution For Men State Prison in Chino. California prisons remain on lockdown after Saturday's riot in Chino. On Aug. 8 a violent riot broke out at the California Institution of Men in the West reception facility. About 200 inmates were injured and 30 remain hospitalized with nonÂlife threatening injuries. Some say the riot is a result of raceÂrelated tensions between Blacks and Latinos.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Los Angeles sheriff's deputy fatally shoots man in South Los Angeles
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy fatally shot a man Tuesday evening in South Los Angeles, according to the Sheriff's Department.
item.content:encoded: A Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy fatally shot a man Tuesday evening in South Los Angeles, according to the Sheriff's Department.

item.title: L.A. County will ask state to allow restaurants, other businesses to reopen sooner
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: L.A. County supervisors say the county has made enough progress in dealing with the coronavirus that they will ask the state to allow more establishments to begin reopening.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County supervisors say the county has made enough progress in dealing with the coronavirus that they will ask the state to allow more establishments to begin reopening.

media:content.media:description: JANICE HAHN,

item.title: L.A. County allows churches, stores, pools, drive-in theaters to reopen with restrictions
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: Los Angeles County announced Tuesday that it will align with California's latest guidelines to allow faith-based services, in-store shopping at low-risk retail stores, drive-in movies and other recreational activities. Beauty salons will still be closed.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County announced Tuesday that it will align with California's latest guidelines to allow faith-based services, in-store shopping at low-risk retail stores, drive-in movies and other recreational activities. Beauty salons will still be closed.

media:content.media:description: BREA, CA - MAY 26: Shoppers come and go from the Brea Mall, which reopened Tuesday, where some of the mall's stores opened their doors to shoppers as the state emerges from shutdown orders enacted to slow the spread of the coronavirus. In new guidelines released yesterday ... the re-opening of retail stores for socially distanced shopping experiences remains subject to approval from officials in each of the state's counties. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 'What the heck is going on?' County supervisors demand answers on Vernon coronavirus outbreaks
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors on Tuesday gave local health officials and plant operators in Vernon one week to review worker safety protocols and report back.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors on Tuesday gave local health officials and plant operators in Vernon one week to review worker safety protocols and report back.

media:content.media:description: The City of Vernon water tower sits along the Los Angeles River. The 45-unit Vernon Villiage Park Apartments complex that is nearing completion is the first privately-owned residence the city will have in decades.

item.title: As inmate deaths and infections rise, Chino, Avenal prisons will test all employees for coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: With nine inmates at Chino prison dead after getting COVID-19, it and Avenal prison will require all staff testing.
item.content:encoded: With nine inmates at Chino prison dead after getting COVID-19, it and Avenal prison will require all staff testing.

media:content.media:description: Housing in the Elm dorm at California Institution for Men in Chino.

item.title: Orange County authorities won't enforce mask requirement: 'We are not the mask police'
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A health order issued Friday requires Orange County residents to wear cloth face coverings when in a public setting.
item.content:encoded: A health order issued Friday requires Orange County residents to wear cloth face coverings when in a public setting.

media:content.media:description: PLACENTIA, CA - MAY 16: Jim Rafferty, owner of one of Orange County's best-known sports bars Kelly's Korner, left, chats with a regular customer on Saturday, May 16, 2020 in Placentia, CA. The sports bar is effectively grounded as the pandemic shutdowns affect restaurants and limit him to take-out. Like most restaurants and bars, Kelly's has had to pivot drastically to survive. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Inland Empire will worship in person after state gives green light
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: In addition to dine-in restaurants and in-person shopping, Riverside and San Bernardino counties are resuming in-person worship services.
item.content:encoded: In addition to dine-in restaurants and in-person shopping, Riverside and San Bernardino counties are resuming in-person worship services.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CALIFORNIA - MAY 8, 2020: Residents who want public health orders rescinded attend an emergency meeting of the Riverside County Board of Supervisors at the County Administrative Center in the midst of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic on May 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. Type written notes are placed on chairs to keep people from sitting near each other. (Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County deems in-person church 'essential,' says rules too restrictive for megachurches
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a resolution supporting the resumption of in-person religious assemblies starting this weekend.
item.content:encoded: The Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a resolution supporting the resumption of in-person religious assemblies starting this weekend.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA-CA-APRIL 12, 2020: MaryAnn Lawson collects prayer requests from people gathering in their cars in a parking lot in Santa Ana to worship in an Easter service by Rev. Robert A. Schuller on Sunday, April 12, 2020. Schuller is reviving a practice that launched his father to worldwide acclaim- the drive-in ministry. For the past four years, the younger Schuller has been preaching primarily on social media, providing daily sermons from his "church with no walls." The COVID-19 outbreak - and the loss of in-person fellowship - led him back to his roots. "People need a place to go to worship on Easter, " he said. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California reopening further, but L.A. County still stymied by coronavirus numbers
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Sarah Parvini
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that barbershops and hair salons would be allowed to reopen in 47 of California's 58 counties. Los Angeles isn't one of them.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that barbershops and hair salons would be allowed to reopen in 47 of California's 58 counties. Los Angeles isn't one of them.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, MAY 6, 2020: Elaina Wilcox, owner of Color & Craft Salon is photographed inside her empty salon on Main St. in Culver City. The salon has been closed since March 19, 2020 because of the coronavirus. Wilcox , who said that her rent is $3200 a month and doesn't have an income right now, fears that she will lose her salon. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Throngs of people, many without masks, pack Venice Beach over Memorial Day weekend
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Californians cooped up for months under coronavirus stay-at-home orders crowded Southern California spots, pushing social distancing limits.
item.content:encoded: Californians cooped up for months under coronavirus stay-at-home orders crowded Southern California spots, pushing social distancing limits.

media:content.media:description: People walk at the boardwalk in Venice Beach during the first day of the Memorial Day holiday weekend amid the novel Coronavirus, COVID-19, pandemic in California on May 23, 2020. - Los Angeles County officials announced May 22, 2020, that beach bike paths and some beach parking lots will reopen and curbside service at indoor malls will be permitted. The county reopened its beaches a week ago but kept beach parking lots, bike paths, piers and boardwalks closed. (Photo by Apu GOMES / AFP) (Photo by APU GOMES/AFP via Getty Images)

(Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hair salons, barbershops can reopen now, in Stage 3 of Newsom's plan; L.A. also loosens some restrictions
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Stephanie Lai
item.description: Gov. Newsom said California barbershops, hair salons, nail salons and other grooming services could reopen under Stage 3 of his reopening plan.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Newsom said California barbershops, hair salons, nail salons and other grooming services could reopen under Stage 3 of his reopening plan.

media:content.media:description: ATWATER, CA - MAY 26, 2020 - - Rosa Pedraza, wearing a protective mask against COVID-19, cuts Robert Nunez' hair at Rosa Hair Salon in Atwater, California on May 26, 2020. Pedraza has owned the business for 17 years in Atwater. California Governor Gavin Newsom says California counties that have been granted regional variances allowing more types of businesses to reopen can now permit the reopening of barbershops and hair salons, with modifications such as protective gear and face coverings. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: The Pasadena hiking spot was shut down Sunday after visitors, many not practicing social distancing due to coronavirus outbreak, crowded the trails.

item.title: Coronavirus 'silent spreaders' become a bigger risk as California reopens
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: There's increasing concern that people infected with COVID-19 who show no signs of illness are playing a large role in the transmission of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: There's increasing concern that people infected with COVID-19 who show no signs of illness are playing a large role in the transmission of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 22: Hainan Airlines flight crew in full biohazard suit at Tom Bradley Terminal. Due to global pandemic and upcoming Memorial Day Weekend travelers are strongly advised to follow mask and social distancing recommendations at Los Angeles International Airport. Los Angeles Airport LAX on Friday, May 22, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Heat wave to bake parts of Southern California, dry out vegetation that can fuel fires
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Triple-digit temperatures are expected in some Southern California inland areas, while the valleys will reach the 90s, according to the weather service.
item.content:encoded: Triple-digit temperatures are expected in some Southern California inland areas, while the valleys will reach the 90s, according to the weather service.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 26: Smokey Bear wears a protective face mask as he warns of High Fire Danger at the Riverside Drive and Los Feliz Blvd entrance to Griffith Park in Los Angeles Tuesday, May 26, 2020 as the Southland's latest heat wave will send the mercury soaring into triple-digit territory raising the risk of heat-related illnesses. In some locations an excessive heat warning will be in effect and temperatures are forecast to be around 20 degrees higher than normal. But even where no excessive warning has been issued ... the heat will be brutal ... especially for those working or participating in outdoor activities.... Griffith Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's battle over reopening churches isn't over despite new coronavirus rules
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin, Alex Wigglesworth, Mike Freeman
item.description: The state's plan will alter religious services in dramatic ways, and it's unlikely to end the push by some churches to allow more regular worship operations.
item.content:encoded: The state's plan will alter religious services in dramatic ways, and it's unlikely to end the push by some churches to allow more regular worship operations.

media:content.media:description: SOUTH PASADENA, CA APRIL 5, 2020: Fr Joe O'Neill gives Mass during the coronavirus pandemic Holy Family Church is closed to the public in South Pasadena, CA April 5, 2020. Normally the church would be filled with parishioners on Palm Sunday. Today the church is livestreaming their Masses. While the church remains closed they say they have more than 10,000 visitors through their our livestreamed Masses. This is the third Mass today during Palm Sunday. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Francine Orr/Francine Orr/Francine Orr/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Banks: Once homeless, a student loses 100 pounds and fends off isolation with teachers' help
item.dc:creator: Sandy Banks
item.description: A Los Angeles high school student fights cornonvirus isolation and distance learning struggles with help from his teachers.
item.content:encoded: A Los Angeles high school student fights cornonvirus isolation and distance learning struggles with help from his teachers.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 21: Keith Wallick, 17,poses for a portrait in his neighborhood South L.A. on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Wallick now lives with his older brother in an apartment in South LA . Wallick struggled in school, until he found art at Santee High School. He is now graduatin with a choice of scholarships to three different college arts programs, and has lost over 100 pounds. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Despite a budget crisis, L.A. officials give new bonuses to officers with college degrees
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith

item.content:encoded: LAPD officers with college degrees have begun receiving a new education bonus, even as civilian city employees are targeted for furloughs.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- MONDAY, JANUARY 28, 2019: Mayor Eric Garcetti, right, listens to LAPD Chief Michel Moore announce that for the first time in five years, violent crime was down in Los Angeles in 2018, with the number of homicides on track to be among the lowest in more than 50 years during a press conference at LAPD headquarters in Los Angeles, Calif., on Jan. 28, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Facing schedule delays, L.A. Metro seeks $120 million more for Crenshaw Line
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: L.A. County transportation officials are seeking $120 million more to complete the $2-billion Crenshaw Line, which will run from Mid-City to the South Bay.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County transportation officials are seeking $120 million more to complete the $2-billion Crenshaw Line, which will run from Mid-City to the South Bay.

media:content.media:description: Artist's rendering of the Crenshaw Line's Century/Aviation station. Officials approved another station Thursday just to the north, at Aviation Boulevard and 96th Street.

item.title: California allows many more retail stores to reopen
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin
item.description: The existing guidance for retailers now applies statewide. It marks the latest move to slowly reopen California's economy amid the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The existing guidance for retailers now applies statewide. It marks the latest move to slowly reopen California's economy amid the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Doug Jordan owner of Java Junction at The Grossmont Center, an outdoor shopping mall in La Mesa, opened his store for the first time since closing in March. The mall opened to the public today with a few gift shops, formal dress shops and a few of the small eat in dining restaurants. Late Wednesday night the State of California approved San Diego County's plan for Phase 2 of the reopening plan.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: L.A. County COVID-19 cases top 46,000 on Memorial Day
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza
item.description: Los Angeles County reported 12 new coronavirus deaths and an additional 1,047 cases Monday.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County reported 12 new coronavirus deaths and an additional 1,047 cases Monday.

media:content.media:description: Children place a flowers at the graves of fallen soldiers to pay their respects during Memorial Day observances at the Los Angeles National Cemetery to honor fallen soldiers and health care workers in Los Angeles, Monday, May 25, 2020. The annual Memorial Day commemoration at the cemetery was held without the public in attendance due to the coronavirus outbreak. (AP Photo/Richard Vogel)

item.title: On Memorial Day, Southern California honors fallen service members and those on the front line of coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Rosanna Xia, Harriet Ryan
item.description: With social distancing rules in place, Memorial Day ceremonies across Southern California were replaced by virtual gatherings.
item.content:encoded: With social distancing rules in place, Memorial Day ceremonies across Southern California were replaced by virtual gatherings.

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump salutes after placing a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery, in honor of Memorial Day, Monday, May 25, 2020, in Arlington, Va. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon)

item.title: Farmer John meatpackers demand closing of Vernon plant struck by COVID-19 outbreak
item.dc:creator: Harriet Ryan
item.description: The union representing workers at the Vernon plant that makes Dodger Dogs said the facility should be shut down pending cleaning and an investigation.
item.content:encoded: The union representing workers at the Vernon plant that makes Dodger Dogs said the facility should be shut down pending cleaning and an investigation.

media:content.media:description: VERNON, CA - NOVEMBER 3, 2017: Farmer John located at Soto St and E. 37th Street in Vernon Friday November 3, 2017 as air quality officials are expected to adopt new rules aimed at easing foul odors from animal rendering plants. Nearby Boyle Heights residents have long complained for about stomach-churning odors wafting over from five Vernon-area rendering plants, which take animal parts from slaughterhouses and cook them down into fats and proteins that are used to make pet food, fertilizer, cosmetics and products. The new standards, which took over three years for regulators to develop amid pushback from the industry, will require facilities enclose some of their outdoor animal processing operations, use odor-control equipment and take other steps to minimize offensive odors. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California limits church capacity to 25% for reopening, adds other restrictions
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin
item.description: California has released new coronavirus health guidance for religious services, limiting total attendance to 25% of a building's capacity.
item.content:encoded: California has released new coronavirus health guidance for religious services, limiting total attendance to 25% of a building's capacity.

item.title: He was a Hollywood darling for fighting dog meat trade. Butchers say he staged killings; he denies it
item.dc:creator: Paul Pringle, Alene Tchekmedyian, David Pierson
item.description: Activist Marc Ching, whose work won support from Joaquin Phoenix, Matt Damon and other celebrities, denies paying butchers in Asia to harm dogs.
item.content:encoded: Activist Marc Ching, whose work won support from Joaquin Phoenix, Matt Damon and other celebrities, denies paying butchers in Asia to harm dogs.

media:content.media:description: The dogs inside the iron cage will be sold at Tomohon Market. Butchers in Indonesia and Cambodia have told The Times that Ching staged scenes by paying them to torture and kill the dogs on camera N including the one that was burned alive N in a manner far more cruel than the methods they normally employ.
media:content.media:credit: Ronny Adolof Buol/For the Times/Ronny Adolof Buol/For the Times/Ronny Adolof Buol

item.title: With masks, temperature checks and anxiety, California's retail economy gingerly reopens
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter, Alex Wigglesworth, Sonali Kohli
item.description: With masks, temperature checks and anxiety, California's retail economy gingerly reopens
item.content:encoded: With masks, temperature checks and anxiety, California's retail economy gingerly reopens

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Bryson Finger serves coffee to Jeric Gambon, 24, as he enjoys breakfast at Busy Bee Cafe on Main Street in downtown Ventura Thursday morning as Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Animal rescue charity with star-studded support has 'troubling' financial practices, experts say
item.dc:creator: Paul Pringle, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: A whistleblower and watchdogs raise concerns over cash withdrawals, allegedly deceptive solicitations and other financial practices at the Animal Hope & Wellness Foundation. The charity denies misleading donors or misusing money.
item.content:encoded: A whistleblower and watchdogs raise concerns over cash withdrawals, allegedly deceptive solicitations and other financial practices at the Animal Hope & Wellness Foundation. The charity denies misleading donors or misusing money.

media:content.media:description: Mandatory Credit: Photo by Broadimage/Shutterstock (10129814az) Shannen Doherty, Marc Ching 2nd Annual Animal Compassion Project Gala, Arrivals, Los Angeles, USA - 03 Mar 2019

item.title: Role of extremist groups at California lockdown protests raises alarms
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Lockdown protesters gathered for another rally at the California Capitol, where alt-right groups mixed with religious rights organizers, anti-vaccine advocates, others.
item.content:encoded: Lockdown protesters gathered for another rally at the California Capitol, where alt-right groups mixed with religious rights organizers, anti-vaccine advocates, others.

media:content.media:description: SACRAMENTO, CA -- MAY 23: A large crowd of roughly 2000 people gathers to attend 'Liberty Fest,' hosted by the Freedom Angels, outside the closed state Capitol building on Saturday, May 23, 2020, in Sacramento, CA. Demonstrators gathered to protest Gov. Gavin Newson's shutdown of businesses and religious gatherings amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Amid coronavirus crisis, L.A. County may create an inspector general to oversee nursing homes
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: More than half of the deaths from COVID-19 in Los Angeles County have been in skilled nursing facilities. On Tuesday, the L.A. County Board of Supervisors will consider a motion to bring more accountability to those sites.
item.content:encoded: More than half of the deaths from COVID-19 in Los Angeles County have been in skilled nursing facilities. On Tuesday, the L.A. County Board of Supervisors will consider a motion to bring more accountability to those sites.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles County Supervisor Mark Ridley-Thomas at a meeting in 2013.

item.title: Coronavirus outbreak hits Farmer John plant in Vernon that makes Dodger Dogs
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: More than 100 workers at the Farmer John plant in Vernon have contracted the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: More than 100 workers at the Farmer John plant in Vernon have contracted the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: VERNON, CA - NOVEMBER 3, 2017: Farmer John located at Soto St and E. 37th Street in Vernon Friday November 3, 2017 as air quality officials are expected to adopt new rules aimed at easing foul odors from animal rendering plants. Nearby Boyle Heights residents have long complained for about stomach-churning odors wafting over from five Vernon-area rendering plants, which take animal parts from slaughterhouses and cook them down into fats and proteins that are used to make pet food, fertilizer, cosmetics and products. The new standards, which took over three years for regulators to develop amid pushback from the industry, will require facilities enclose some of their outdoor animal processing operations, use odor-control equipment and take other steps to minimize offensive odors. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Catholic Church in Orange County plans to reopen in 'small steps' beginning June 14
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Catholic Church in Orange County plans to reopen in 'small steps' beginning June 14
item.content:encoded: Catholic Church in Orange County plans to reopen in 'small steps' beginning June 14

media:content.media:description: Bishop Kevin Vann in front of Christ Cathedral in Garden Grove. The design plan for transforming the iconic structure was revealed Wednesday.

item.title: Pancakes, face masks, temperature checks: Ventura County restaurants reopen to customers, concerns
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: Eating inside restaurants is now allowed in Ventura County.
item.content:encoded: Eating inside restaurants is now allowed in Ventura County.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CALIFORNIA MAY 23, 2020-An employee at Finney's Crafthouse prepares the bar to open Thursday in Ventura Saturday. The county lifted a lockdown for sit down dining at all restaurants.(Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 18: Testing for coronavirus Covid-19 is being conducted at St. John's Well Child and Family Center in South Los Angeles located at 808 West 58th Street; one of the South and Central LA neighborhoods hit hard by the coronavirus Covid-19. South Central on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: William Lyon, Orange County real estate magnate who foresaw region's growth, dies at 97
item.dc:creator: Mike Anton
item.description: Orange County real estate magnate William Lyon, who built more than 100,000 homes nationwide and helped shape suburban America, has died at 97.
item.content:encoded: Orange County real estate magnate William Lyon, who built more than 100,000 homes nationwide and helped shape suburban America, has died at 97.

item.title: Court upholds Newsom's coronavirus ban on in-person church services in California
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli, Matthew Ormseth
item.description: The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld California Gov. Gavin Newsom's ban on in-person church services due to the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld California Gov. Gavin Newsom's ban on in-person church services due to the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: Wally Thomas of Lake Forest and Denean MacAndrew of Mission Viejo take part in a protest in Huntington Beach on May 9, 2020.

item.title: A new coronavirus testing site is opening at Dodger Stadium: What you need to know
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti announced a new coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium. Here's what you need to know.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti announced a new coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium. Here's what you need to know.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-MARCH 26, 2020: The public entrance to Dodger Stadium is closed on what would have been opening day if not for the coronavirus outbreak. At far right is an employee entrance. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County cleared to reopen more businesses amid coronavirus restrictions
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Hannah Fry
item.description: coronavirus: Orange County gets the OK for more aggressive reopening
item.content:encoded: coronavirus: Orange County gets the OK for more aggressive reopening

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA BEACH, CALIF. - MAY 2, 2020. Cops and protesters find a shady spot along Pacific Coast Highway in Laguna Beach on Saturday, May 2, 2020. California Gov. Gavin Newson ordered a hard closure of Orange County beaches this weekend. But responding to public pressure in recent days, Newson has implied that a gradual reopening of beaches, parks and the economy following the coronavirus lockdown could begin as early as next week. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California just made it easier for bars, wineries, distilleries to offer to-go drinks
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: More California establishments can sell alcoholic beverages to go after the state relaxed a rule to help businesses during the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: More California establishments can sell alcoholic beverages to go after the state relaxed a rule to help businesses during the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: Bartender Taylor Osorio wears a face mask as she pours drinks at Centro Cocina Mexicana restaurant in Sacramento, Calif., Friday, May 22, 2020. As part of Sacramento County's extended Stage 2 reopening plan, dine-in restaurants and retail stores were allowed to open at noon Friday after being closed for several months due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: How L.A. County became coronavirus epicenter: Slower shutdown, density, poverty among theories
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: Theories abound as to why L.A. County has the bulk of the state's confirmed coronavirus cases, but a clear explanation has been elusive.
item.content:encoded: Theories abound as to why L.A. County has the bulk of the state's confirmed coronavirus cases, but a clear explanation has been elusive.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- MONDAY, APRIL 6, 2020: Dusk settles as the Third street which is usually streaming with traffic, sits empty in downtown Los Angeles, Calif., on April 6, 2020. In California, there are more than 16,363 confirmed COVID-19 cases, according to a tally maintained by the Los Angeles Times. At least 387 have died. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)
